title: Zai Pit Water Harvesting Revival
summary: Farmer innovator Yacouba Sawadogo revived the traditional zai pit technique to rehabilitate degraded land in Burkina Faso's Sahel, contributing to the restoration of 200,000-300,000 hectares of barren land and yield increases of 300-400% across the Central Plateau.

keyData.label: Organic Matter Added
keyData.value: 0.6 kg compost or manure per pit

content:
## Background

Burkina Faso's Central Plateau, home to the dense Mossi population, experienced severe land degradation during the droughts of the 1970s and 1980s. Decades of population growth, overgrazing, deforestation, and successive drought years created vast expanses of hardpan laterite soil known locally as zipelle, land so crusted and compacted that rainwater simply ran off without penetrating the surface. Across the Sahel, millions of hectares were considered permanently lost to desertification.

The ecological crisis was intertwined with a food security emergency. Burkina Faso's population roughly doubled between 1960 and 1985, placing enormous pressure on agricultural land while rainfall declined by 20-30% compared to the 1950s-1960s average. Crop yields on degraded lands fell to near zero. Outmigration from the Central Plateau to cities and to Cote d'Ivoire's cocoa belt accelerated, draining rural communities of their most productive members.

Conventional development responses, including large-scale mechanical soil conservation projects funded by donors, proved expensive, technically complex, and difficult to maintain. Stone bunds and earthen dikes installed by development projects were sometimes abandoned when project funding ended. The situation seemed intractable until the resurgence of interest in indigenous soil and water conservation techniques, particularly the zai pit.

## The Intervention

The zai is a traditional planting pit technique originating among the Dogon people of Mali and historically practiced in parts of Burkina Faso. Yacouba Sawadogo, a farmer from Gourga village in Yatenga Province, is credited with innovating and popularizing a modified version beginning in the early 1980s. Sawadogo's key innovation was adding organic matter, including compost and dry-season animal manure, into the pits, which attracted termites whose tunneling activity further broke up the hardpan and improved soil structure and water infiltration.

The technique involves digging small pits approximately 20-30 centimeters in diameter and 10-20 centimeters deep, spaced roughly 80 centimeters apart in staggered rows across degraded land. Each pit receives approximately 0.6 kilograms of organic matter before the rainy season. Seeds of millet or sorghum are planted in the pits, which concentrate scarce rainfall directly at the root zone. The excavated soil is placed downslope of each pit to form a small ridge that captures additional runoff.

Critically, the zai technique was combined with farmer-managed natural regeneration (FMNR), the practice of protecting and managing naturally sprouting tree and shrub seedlings rather than planting nursery-raised trees. As documented extensively by Chris Reij of the World Resources Institute, farmers across the Central Plateau allowed trees to regenerate on their fields, creating agroforestry parklands that improved soil fertility through nitrogen fixation, provided fodder and fuelwood, and moderated microclimate. Reij, Tappan, and Smale (2009) documented this transformation as one of the largest environmental rehabilitation efforts in Africa.

## Results & Evidence

Reij, Tappan, and Smale (2009) used satellite imagery, aerial photography, and ground-truthing to estimate that between 200,000 and 300,000 hectares of degraded land on Burkina Faso's Central Plateau had been rehabilitated through zai pits, FMNR, and related techniques by the mid-2000s. Comparative analysis of aerial photographs from the 1960s and satellite images from 2005 showed significantly increased tree cover in many areas, reversing the assumed trajectory of desertification.

Agronomic studies demonstrated that zai pits increased grain yields by 300-400% compared to traditional flat planting on degraded soils. Sawadogo and colleagues at INERA (Burkina Faso's national agricultural research institute) measured millet yields of 400-900 kg/ha on zai-rehabilitated fields compared to 0-200 kg/ha on adjacent untreated degraded land. The combination of water harvesting and organic matter addition created a positive feedback loop, with improved soil biology further enhancing infiltration and fertility over successive seasons.

Sawadogo's work gained international recognition, including the Right Livelihood Award in 2018 and the subject of the documentary film "The Man Who Stopped the Desert" (2010). The zai technique spread across the Sahel through farmer-to-farmer exchange, NGO training programs, and government extension services. By the 2010s, variations of the technique were practiced in Niger, Mali, Senegal, and other Sahelian countries, contributing to what some researchers termed a "re-greening" of the Sahel.

## Challenges & Criticisms

The zai technique is extremely labor-intensive, requiring an estimated 300-400 hours of work per hectare during the dry season when soils are workable. This labor requirement limits adoption by households with insufficient labor, particularly female-headed households and the elderly. Access to organic matter, particularly animal manure, is another constraint, as the poorest households often do not own livestock. Some researchers, including Sawadogo et al. (2001), noted that adoption rates varied significantly by wealth class and labor availability.

Questions remain about the relative contribution of rainfall recovery versus human intervention to the Sahel's re-greening. Rainfall in parts of the Sahel has partially recovered since the 1990s, and some researchers argue that natural regeneration would have occurred even without farmer intervention. The sustainability of the technique under continued population pressure and potential future droughts is also uncertain. Nevertheless, the broad consensus in the literature, as articulated by Reij and others, is that farmer innovation, including zai pits and FMNR, has been a significant driver of landscape restoration.

## Key Lessons

- Indigenous technical knowledge, adapted and innovated by local farmers, can be more effective, affordable, and sustainable than externally designed interventions for dryland restoration.
- Combining water harvesting (zai pits) with natural resource management (FMNR) creates synergies that produce landscape-scale transformation when adopted by large numbers of farmers.
- Farmer-to-farmer dissemination is often more effective than top-down extension for spreading agroecological innovations, as demonstrated by the rapid spread of zai across the Central Plateau.
- Labor intensity is both a strength (low cash cost, uses dry-season labor) and a weakness (excludes labor-poor households), requiring complementary approaches for the most vulnerable.
- Environmental rehabilitation and food security can be simultaneously achieved through approaches that work with ecological processes rather than against them.
